values:
We have had some surprises with the zucchini.
First, the fact that were big enough to harvest in late june/early july.  Second, when I ignored them for a few days they looked like this:
Lolcat suggestions are encouraged. 

Dave and I were impressed,  he's been growing zucchini for a while and has never gotten them that big.  We were beginning to think it had crossed with the pumpkin (zumpkin!) when Dave found a second one.  Apparently warm nights make zucchini grow quick.   I wish it did something for the eggplants.

I took pictures I never got around to posting, and now some of the plants in them have died! 
I'll post them anyway. 
 
The containers are the same, just everything is bigger.  The potatoes are huge and starting to flower.  It makes me realize that I've never seen a potato flower.

  
The zucchini are also massive, taking up much of that area.

 
 
These cucumbers got eaten by a rabbit.  The leaves on one were still pretty big so I left it there.  The stalks of the remaining three got moved by the zucchini where they were buried under mulch by the well meaning landlady.  She also stepped on one of my tomato plants. 
I bought three new tomato plants to replace the cucumbers since the rabbit didn't touch the other ones.  When the super found out he got mad and brought me 4 more tomato plants. 

 
The pea trellis was the end of the garden until the new tomatoes came, now there are four tomatoes, two parsley, and two basils at the end.  The snap peas are doing much better, but the english peas died.

This is an old look at the whole thing.  It just looks a lot greener now.

I tried swiss chard for the first time last night.  We had a bunch in from the veggie CSA so I boiled it and then fried it in garlic and red pepper flakes.  It tastes just like spinach, just not as strong a flavor.  I'm not a fan of spinach, but I could see cooking it in something else as I had to do tonight.  For some reason, one of the parsley plants has been chopped down.  I'd blame the rabbit again but the basils were untouched.  The recipe said spinach could be substituted, and the chard made a good substitution for that.

I'm not very good at keeping track of log books, and it looks like I'll need a reliable log for my garden this year.  Hence, this journal.
It's at a new house, and as far as I know the soil has never been gardened before.  I'm sending the soil in for testing tomorrow, but I've already planted a few things.   Though, I think I should start the story of my garden at the beginning, on the first weekend of May. 
To start, here is the land:


Not much, but I'm making the most of it.  I'm also adding a lot of containers.  The first of which is the herbs, which are growing on the front porch:

(That's basil, parsely, oregano, and cilantro.)

The next being the potatoes:


The one on the left is a seed potato, the one on the right is an old potato that started growing so I just threw it in some dirt.  From what I've been told, they make nice leaves but not many potatoes.

I also tried to grow strawberries from a small box of roots that I bought at Home Depot.  It didn't work.  I didn't really expect it to, it just that since they are more of an early spring crop, I didn't think the nursery would have any.  Turns out they do.  Dirt cheap, a dollar for two plants.

The following weekend, May 10, our landlord showed up to check the lock.  When I mentioned the garden, he went back to his house and brought over 10 tomato seedlings and about as many swiss chard.  The tomatoes are Rutgers, Big Boys, Ox Hearts, and something he called Grape Strawberry.  They're suppose to be grape tomatoes that taste like strawberries.  It should make for an interesting jam. 

After two weeks of heavy rain, the tomatoes are looking a little week, and some of the chard is dying.  Part of that is my fault for planting them so close together.  In that time though, I also managed to get another window box just for peppermint and a container for two onion sets.  I have no clue how onions grow, and since I thought the price of one set was $1.25, I figured they must grow off of them like potatoes.  As I watch them grow, I'm beginning to see the error of my ways.  It was probably 5 for $1.25, and it looks like I'm only going to have two onions.

A few days ago (20th) I was home sick and decided to walk to the nursery to pick up some more plants.  I'm paranoid that if I don't get everything in by the end of may it won't grow, and it doesn't help any that the nursery is, litterally, two blocks from my house.  I came back with some strawberries, eggplant and zucchini.

Today I planted some sugar snap peas that I had grown from seed.  I was very proud of myself for making a trellis out of an old piece of Dougie's cage.  The english peas haven't grown tall enough, but when they do, they will join their sweeter cousins.  This weekend should be the end of it, with me getting a container ready for those strawberries, planting a few cucumbers, and setting up a container of hot peppers for David.

Updated pictures coming soon!

I went to Barcelona.  Here are pictures: http://www.flickr.com/photos/7794300@N03/sets
We went to a concert while there, but I didn't take a camera in.  Other people took pictures of us, so they may end up on the concert's website with captions like "Oh No, Americans!  Run before they bomb us!" 

I started a garden, as it turns out, on our neighboors property.  They said they didn't mind, but next year they plan to use it.  I'm also trying to make a compost bin, but since I started it before i got a drill results have been fly ridden and less than succesfull. 
I'm trying to be a little more eco friendly, the word trying being used losely there.  I still haven't made a habit of biking to the grocery store, I don't go to farmer's markets, I haven't replaced all my lightbulbs, and I don't intentially buy organic/local.  It bugs me, but i know Dave is thrilled.  Since I started reading the often whiny sometimes informative "No Impact Man" blog and various other eco friendly networks, he thought I might go overboard for a week and spend the next month cleaning up (as tends to happen when I try new hobbies).  I still intend to try, it would be healthier and save money (since it costs $30 to fill my gas tank now).  
More for my interests, it gives me a chance to do old fashion kitchen stuff, which I love.  I'm going to try the wine again and I plan on buying canning equipment.  I don't like jam so much, but hopefully there will be more tomatoes than I can fit in sauces and salads.  I know there will be an excess of peppers, but I still need to reserch how to can/pickle/dry those.

"There is one game you must never play, burying yourself in a block of cement.  That's the worst game of all."
-Love Me if You Dare

yeah, i'm real observant.
My palm piolt, Dave's camera, binoculars, and camcorder are gone.
I know what I'm buying this christmas...

It's a late night with no Dave, so naturally I can't sleep.  

I was browsing wikipedia when I found out that Semester at Sea has left Pitt, I gather at some point last year.  Okay so it's no big surprise that it took me this long to find that out, but it still feels weird when stuff here changes.  The parklet was okay, the American Apperal store I'm lukewarm about, I guess I still hoped that it would be a theatre again.

I'm trying to grow my hair out because I had bangs and hated them.  A few days ago Dave told me to go to a sylist and that he would pay.  Of course, he repharsed it as an option later, but I never know what to say in those situations.  I know my hair is a mess I just don't really care about it; but if  I say that to him he'll try to make me care and just leave me feeling insecure.  And he's one of those type, say one bad and it always comes up later: 
"We don't have to go out tonight"  
"No, you say we never go out, so we're going out"  
"I said that last year!"  
"So are you saying you're a liar?"
*sigh* I still miss him.

I started another cross stich.  Any bets on how long it will take me?  

I have to move the skulls in the dental school tomorrow.  Orginally they were going to go in the computer lab/study lounge, but I guess there wasn't enough room, because now they're going to the empty office across the hall.  Ideally, they're for public viewing, so students can look at all the cavities, overbite, and probably not notice at all that most of the skulls are from african americans with such interesting tags as "hottontot" and "executed negro".  For the record, the skulls were either donated by anthropologist or bought at curiosity shops, certainly not harvested or recruted from patients.  Or at least all evidence seems to point to that, all offcial records and personal information pertaining to the skulls has been long since lost or destroyed save the occasional tag.  One skull is green, I don't know what's up with that.  I'd be happy to give a tour if you're in the area.  Any way, I've have strayed from my first point of "scientific racism" and how looking at these skulls led me to look up human zoos.  I was surprised to see that there were numerous instances, and a bit of popularity, in the late 1800's of putting people kidnapped from colonies in zoo side by side with wild animals.  It's disturbing to think about.  

But again, I am rather late in learning of these things.

We didn't notice it when we first moved in, perhaps because it wasn't there, perhaps because of the way it camouflaged with rocks, but finally I commented "there is a dead squirrel in our front yard."
David initially thought it was cool, apparently he has never seen a dead squirrel before.  I had seen one, but it didn't last long on the sidewalk.  I assumed there was some natural mechanism in which these things were disposed of (ex: feral cats).  The days went by and the squirrel lingered.  It smelled horrible for about a day, then we either got used to it or the smell lessened.  The flies were growing in number.  
I estimate it had been there about a week when we finally decided to remove it.  This was last Sunday.  I suggested calling Animal Control, but a google searched proved animal removal to be out of their jurisdiction.  We considered calling the landlord, but decied it was too late for that, since the head was already eaten through.  
Of course, neither of us knew the "proper" way to dispose of a decaying animal but we knew the hazards.  The insects that were now feeding on it could be carrying diseases and the thing did smell bad.  Our plan: dose the remains in a bleach solution, shovel it into a bag, put it out with the trash.  I wanted to bury it, for fear of it causeing a health hazard while being mashed up in the garbage truck.  David ignored this request and I'm glad he did.
I didn't watch the bleach solution being poured, but David said it "smoked as bugs poured out it".  From the stoop I could still see the river of maggots that flowed down the sidewalk.  
David: Jesus!  Look at all those maggots!
Me: Oh God!
David: And cockroaches!
Me: OH GOD!
Three doses later, David shoveled the remains into a plastic bag lined box, which we then put in a garbage bag.  Afterwards we were both pretty solemn, not knowing what to say.  Part of David's job involved dissecting pigs, so i didn't think he would mind the clean up as much as i would.  He still seemed shaken.  "Well, I've smelled worse, but seeing that earthworm crawl out of it's belly."  He reconsidered, "we crawl from under the skin of it's belly, that was pretty fucked up."    
Finally  David said, "Kat are sure that was a squirrel?"  "Pretty sure, why?"  "Well, I didn't see any fur on it's tail.  I think it may have been a rat."

On a lighter note, I start Latin Dance lessons today!
I got a cell phone.  It has a camera.

The big news in my life now is getting a new place.  It's the bottom floor of a old house, but it seems pretty nifty.  It's got a sunroom, a backporch with grapes growing on it, and parking.  And hardwood floors, which will cause much stress for the bunny and much entertainment for us.
Oh yeah, and I'll be living there with Dave.  And there will be many culinary exploites!

I made perogies last night for the first time.  It went pretty well, though now i have an excess of potato-cheese filing.  Hopefully it will make nice biscuits.  
Through the live journal "candyisawesome", I got a shipment of south american candy.  Combined with easter candy, hard candy i can never get rid of, and chocolate bars i buy and forget about, I have too much candy.  The south american stuff is kind of neat, one of the items was a piece of guava paste, which looked a lot like a squishy bit of hash.  It also wasn't labeled, there was just a note in the package.  David thinks it's all contaminated.  
On Sunday, I get to go to David's graduation.  Not really looking forward to it, as I didn't enjoy my graduation which he refused to go to.  It is different, they'll actually call his name and give him his diploma on stage.  It will also be a chance to see his whole family, watch them fight, and quickly run away.  
I don't know why, but part of me wants to see the scene his mother will inevitable make.  I know i'll hate it at the time and that I'll probably be too scared to really leave.  Like watching a car wreck, maybe?

after my long hiatus spent researching contemporary art in France and eating chocolate, I return to live journal. 
I got a new job at Pitt, in the Dental School, which has been cool and laid back so far.
everything else has relatively nifty, though I don't enjoy it much because I am often very tired.  
while walking by a church of science the other day, I began wondering if religion wasn't just a way for humans to justify their difference from animals.  Humans are here for pretty much the same reasons ferrets are here, chance evolution.  Humans reached a point, though, where they dramatically started altering their environment negating evolution and adaptation to a degree.  why not the ferrets?  Why did humans get this self descrutive bend while ferrets still hop around and eat prairie dogs?  Then again, even when one rejects religion, they don't go completely feral.  To be an animal would mean rejecting all of history and art and most people seem unwilling to do so.  My mind wanders too much.
For the price of 20 new bunnies, I got my rabbit spayed.  She's been pretty good since then, not attaching me or growling at me.      
I died my hair red.

I made potato biscuts, and they were quite good.
Then I went it Dave's house and made cookies.  He thought it would be fun to make a bunch of different kinds of cookies with his nephews, but his sister isn't speaking to him for some reason.  She's keeping her kids away from him as well.  
The cookies, however, were also quite good.

so i am at my last day of work, writing a paper that should be e-mailed in to my professor today.  It's a horrible paper and it's almost exactly half as long as she wanted it.  I really can't make myself care about it now, though I know I'll care later when I see a C or worst on my report card.  I feel like a waste.  Just the way of it.  Tomorrow I can go to bed, maybe wake up and bake some bread, maybe just go for a walk.  It should be fun.

You Are 40% Boyish and 60% Girlish
You are pretty evenly split down the middle - a total eunuch. Okay, kidding about the eunuch part. But you do get along with both sexes. You reject traditional gender roles. However, you don't actively fight them. You're just you. You don't try to be what people expect you to be.
How Boyish or Girlish Are You?

okay, i've had my little bitch session and I feel the better for it.  Though, after checking the security on my account, I have to admend a few comments.  My accound only allows comments from registered users, so they really couldn't have comment.  It also dosen't have my real name or is aviable to search engines.  I'mm going to up the security later, sleep now

My LiveJournal Trick-or-Treat Haul
quiet_punk goes trick-or-treating, dressed up as dead rabbit hearder.
blankbooks tricks you! You get a dead frog.
entropyfiend tricks you! You get a used tissue.
ooglemonster gives you 18 purple apple-flavoured pieces of chewing gum.
patmorita tricks you! You get a rotten egg.
plastikgirl gives you 12 brown root beer-flavoured pieces of chewing gum.
salixus23 tricks you! You lose 8 pieces of candy!
siciliandonkey gives you 11 dark green cherry-flavoured wafers.
stalicia tricks you! You lose 6 pieces of candy!
teffymae gives you 11 mauve pineapple-flavoured wafers.
quiet_punk ends up with 38 pieces of candy, a dead frog, a used tissue, and a rotten egg.
Go trick-or-treating! Username:
Another fun meme brought to you by rfreebern.

boring random day.  we got into protein folding in class and I didn't understand the majority of it.  When I got back to the lab I started looking up books on how to teach a kid good manner.  There are so many of them!  Only a few directed at the kids, most are for the parents.  There's potential to reach a conclusion about a growing ruder society, but Emily Post has been around a while.  I still think guilt and hellfire is a good way to get kids to straighten up, but with antheists, I don't know.  
Concert Plug!!! Tonight, 7PM, Club Cafe, Troubbled Hubble!  They have songs about Canada and canoes!  I wish I could invite the band to my place to play apples to apples, but there is no parking.

I took Douglas to the vet for a check up.  
Turns out, Douglas is a girl.

After 4 months, I like to think she knows what Douglas means, so I'm not going to bother changing her name.

who's up for hitchhikers?  and more importantly, who's up for dressing up and looking like a dork?
I call Marvin.

Got the weekend all to myself, Dave is off in Seattle for the College Bowl Nationals.  I will spend most of that time writing my final paper, but hopefully i'll get in some good girly alone time.  
So last night, I had to put douglas in his cage, and not giving it much thought i picked him up without wearing a shirt.  Now I have scratches down my stomach and across my left tit.  That rabbit is such a bitch sometimes.
Our nonfiction teacher handed out random books to everyone the last day of class.  I got another copy of the Wasteland.  I like the poem and all, but this is the fourth copy I have now.  It's not even a good Norton's one, just Barnes and Nobles.  I would have traded, but most of the class had already said they hated poetry.  And come on, you really can't trade up with that.

Release reading for the issue of Three Rivers Review I actually worked on is tonight.  
Hemingway's, 9:30, free food and if anyone who reads this shows up I'll buy your drinks.
And of course, there will be lots of in jokes and mediocre fiction.  Bring your own, it's open mike
!

isn't it cute how the thirsty kitten cries?

I slept with a stuff animal last night for the first time in ages.  When I woke up I was still holding it.  That's better than I do with most people.

http://www.dieselsweeties.com/archive.php?s=1189

always good for a one-liner.  

I'm going to a wine tasting at the Warhol, anyone want to join me?

I was listening to the beginning of Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata on the way to work and I thought "man this is so familiar, yet fantastic."  Then it got into this poorly played happy second part, then it got to the third part and I realized this is the Beethoven song.  You know, when ever shows talk about classic music they all play the same tune by the person because everyone already knows it.  Beethoven's is the third movement of Moonlight Sonata.  Ode to Joy stands alone.  
I let douglas run around the apartment without supervision last night.  It seemed to work out, nothing chewed up or unpleasantly damp.  He's getting more social, but he still won't play with his toys.
fuzzy but still good picture

Still couldn't figure out how to load pictures without paying for this account.  So my icon is now a little picture of douglas.
-Enjoy!

I got a bunny!
He's small, soft, grey and scared to death of me!
Dave it got for me, partly for valentines, partly because he thinks I'm lonely too much.  It's a hard critter to warm up to.  It doesn't bit or scratch so much, but every time I leave it out of the cage it leaves pellets all over the floor.  I haven't much choice in though, it's not healthy to leave it in a cage all day.  Different websites say they get over that as they learn the limits of their territory.  He's also addicted to his water bottle.  I added this vitamin C supplement to it, so maybe that makes it taste sweet or something.  He just gnaws at all day.  And he's box trained.  I had no idea that bunnies used litter boxes, but apparently they do; to a extent though.  
I named him Douglas, because I like the name and because it's Dave's middle name.
If I figure out how to post pictures, I'll be sure to put his up.

I'm doing that thing again, where I put too much preparation into something that I know doesn't matter and will be quickly forgotten.  

I turned in my first paper for fiction yesterday, after a week of much "what the hell am I doing in this class?"  It still wasn't a good paper, but ofter reviewing some other ones in the class, I know it wasn't hte worst.  We had to review one by the adult student in the class, a 60 year old polish woman.  Her essay was a static, simplistic presentation of living through Warsaw during Nazi occupation, with syntax that would make a 8th grader cringe.  At first I wrote this off to her not knowing english too well.  But by the end of the essay I find out she has been living in America for 40 years and she has a master's degree.  So annoying.  Downright painful essay.  But I know, next class when I have to criticize her to her face she's going to give everybody that "I'm old and she's hurting me, why?" look and I'll look evil because that's not going to stop me from saying "you waste my time! half of this essay is completely useless information!"

I want to go to bed, but probably I'll go to frick or the grocery store instead.  

sigh

I got a new toy!
It's a palm pilot, it keeps my calender and public domain books!  I often find myself in a situation where I need a book.  You know, just waiting for a bus, hanging out in an empty lab, thinking, "Damn, I've always wanted to read 'O Pioneers'".  And now, just whip out the palm pilot and look at it for 5 minutes, get bored or self conscience and stop.  
Yippee!
And Stacy, I need my baking dish back to make shepherds pie.
Yippee!

Last night the neighbors were fighting again.  The ones next door, a young couple, early twenties, not the people below with a kid.  It always goes the same way, she's yelling about something so loud people I'm talking to on the phone can hear her, and if he responds it's not audible.  I think it's in chinese, but I've never been good with languages.  Last night was a peak though, she just started screaming.  Not "stop hitting me" screams, long loud "I'm fucking sick of this" screams.  I wondered if I should call the police and report a domestic disturbance, like they alway do in sitcoms during abuse awareness week.  But as far as I can tell she wasn't being physically hurt.  And I don't know these people.  Of all the ways to meet your neighbor, calling the police on them is probable one of the worst.  Though, in college town probable fairly common.  Of course, if it is just her being sick of him but not wanting to leave for some reason, police intervention won't help   
Seems like whenever I try to live alone, someone is always screaming at my doorstep.

You see this weather out there?  37 degrees, rain and cold?  I'm going to be running 2 miles in that.  If at any point today you feel bad, think about that, and laugh at me. 
Though, on the plus side, I ran 1/4 of a mile without stopping yesterday.  Not impressive, but very good for me.  
It's been one of those days were I just have to keep telling myself "there will come a time when this day will end, and then you can have hot cocoa" to keep from crying.  
I saw "A very long engagement" last night, and it was pretty good.  A little hard to keep all the characters straight, but still good.

So i'll be in the lab alone until January.  Very good for me, very bad for the project.  Though considering that the sequencing results came back highly fucked I can't mess things up too badly.  
I've been surprisingly productive in the past few days.  Productive, in my definition, are actions that contribute to self-improvement.  So while I have nothing tangible to show for my nights of reading/exercising, I am a little stretchy-er.
WQED had been playing christmas carols and classical renditions of christmas carols which is only sort of annoying.
Tonight I'm going to attempt to make a Boston Cream Pie, actually a cake with custard filling.  I haven't got a good track record with cream fillings.  Usually they're too thin, spill out from the sides of the cake and start to take over the floor.  It's not so bad until they start putting up flags and composing national anthems, then I really have no choice but to destroy their fledgling community.

37. WHAT DID YOU DO LAST NIGHT? tried to do work, gave up and went to Dave's, cuddled, came back, tried to finish sense and senibility, fell asleep in my clothes
38. FAVORITE SMELLS? quite fond of vanilla

enterbacter cloacae is love
brought to you by the isLove Generator

The other day I was sipping a cup of coffee as NPR rattled off the headline for the day: "a plague of locusts is devouring crops in Senegal and West Africa.  This is Morning Edition".  My initial reaction was "what, just one headline?" quickly followed by "a plague of locusts? Like in the biblical sense?".  
I assumed these sorts of things happen all the time, and that it wasn't that serious.  Today I find out I was half right, these plagues are regular enough to be predicted and prevented, however, most nations were not willing to give aid to pre-empt the onslaught, resulting in 90% crop destruction (the number probably a mistake on my part).  The UN is currently deploying food aid and insecticide.
Someone has to say it: So we'll make a pre-emptive strike against possible military threats but not againt actual humanitarian threats.
So I got a hair cut recently.  An actual haircut too,  chopped off to the shoulders and bangs hanging down in the front.  I wasn't too pleased, but nothing I can do about it now.  I had just assumed that when I walked into a salon and said "I want it short, what do you suggest?" the stylist would be excited, take advantage of a 'blank canvas', and rattle off many suggestions.  Instead she was confused and kept saying, "so what do you want? do you want layers?"  It had been Dave's idea that I go to a salon and pay a lot of money to get it professionally styled.  A week or two before he talked his sister into taking me shopping for more feminine clothes.  He seems convinced that if he can make me look like a beautiful women in the conventional sense I'll be happier with myself and more inclined to take some initiative in my life.  A noble effort, but I still say fuck that, I just feel like a phony.  And of course, I can say that without reply as he is morally oppose to livejournals("they're too self-indulgent") and doesn't read mine.
Got an interview with PittMed, went, bombed it, but it dosen't really matter since they were looking for someone with more experience anyway.
I've been working at the Three Rivers Review this semester, and dispite the fact that it has made the glaring fact that I can't write all the more clear, I'm planning on reading at the release party.  It's something I've always wanted to do but have been a little afraid to.  Dave had given me the impression that he would read, so I thought I'd have a solidarity/support base this time.  When asked, he declined ("my stuff is too personal for this crowd"), and I immediately wanted to get out of it.  I suppose I should, I really can't that well and I haven't anything really prepared.  Grrr.  Regardless and certainly, everyone on the list is invited: Monday the 22 at 9o'clock, at Hemingway's, free food (vegetarian provided) but you have to pay for the drinks.
I feel like I've bad mouthed Dave too much in this e-mail, but I think that's more a reflection of how much he's become a part of my life than any sort of dislike.  We had a lovely time this weekend, just hanging out an cuddling.  Early on he had given me a plain chain that had some meaning to him for me to wear as a reminder.  I thought that was cute and did until I lost it about three weeks ago.  I havn't stopped looking for it since, despite him saying it's not important.  Saturday he gave me a necklace with a heart shaped pendant, pink sapphires set in white gold, to replace the function of the plain chain: a daily reminder that he loves me.  
Still, a freaking plague of locusts!  Is it even on the news?

for those of you who doubted the humor of "a softer world" I ask you look at today's entry:

So after much prodding by others and a little by myself I finally made some motions towards career searching in writing.  My discoveries: 1)most schools do not offer degrees in technical writing, but rather join it with business writing under the title "professional communications", except this little school in Philadelphia that seem quite proud of its biomedical writing program.  2)It is still possible to get an internship with PittMed, though too late to use my "well I was talking with your boss..." line.  I'm not sure what kind of writing samples they want, but I know a few good people I can ask.  3) Pitt offers no classes in 'technical' writing, tempting me to look into classes on how to write art reviews.  Though, perhaps the advisors can fill me in if professional writing would be better.  Man, I should totally call Post-Gazette or the like and see if they accept free-lance theatre reviews.  Good thinking live journal!
Been a bland day besides that.  I'm fixing to go vote after work, which entails going out to the Municipal building in Hankey Farms over in Imperial.  And, like many who will be reading this, I will chose the lesser of two evils.  Voting just gets more demoralizing every 4 year.  Perhaps I should start giving a damn about local politics.  We all found it kind of funny, the representative for Fayette Township, Mr. Pippy, was called into training for military service just as he began his campaign.  His wife and friends ran the campaign for him, and he won.  Served his time in Iraq to.  The idea of not be present for your own rallies and the like strikes me as amusing.
But I don'd know about Kerry.  Certainly, anybody would do a better job than Bush, but Kerry is going to be a mouthpiece for the modern democratic party, which has eroding into the old republican party.  Though considering the modern republican party has degraded into a "movement toward regression" perhaps I shouldn't complain.  Ah well, sayeth the cynic, Kerry/Edwards in '04, Bush/Cheney in the lower circles of hell.

when i walked out of my building today, i looked up and saw a black stripe of birds.  For a good 2 to 3 seconds there were enough birds to form a band in the patch of sky between my building and the one next to it.  I'm truly curious as to what prompted it, and whether it happens often or not.

so who all has heard about the voter fraud carried out by some creative republicans?  A few people posing as marijuana advocates were asking people to sign a rather detailed petition for legalization.  Actually, they were voter registation change of address forms.  They then filled in a random district, changed the affiliation to republican, and turned in the forms.  So now, if said signer goes to vote at his usual location, he will be denied.  As clever/stupid as this sounds, I actually know somebody who got taken in by it, one of the staff members at three rivers review.  I can't remember his real name, so lets call him Rick.  
Now Lauren, one of the editors, pointed out to Rick, how stupid it was to give that much information for a legalize it petition.  Pleading a general weakness to weed, he related another story to reinforce this.  One day, he decided to take the stairs to his apartment rather than the elevator.  In the stairwell, he came upon a small bag of marijuana.  Thinking it a bit of providence for having made a healthy choice, he decided to smoke it, and ended up in the emergency room.  Seems it was laced with some sort of amphetamine.    
He thinks it's a conspiracy.  
We all thought he needs to lay off the pipe.

I got to work early with the intention of finishing a story that's due today.  Didn't happen, I perpetuated an old search instead.  
When I was really young I can remember my mother singing a song to me about penny candy and an irish family falling into poverty, but there's still hope cause the mother has a penny for the kid.  A vague recollection of the tune and one verse is all I had, but through a recent series of events (are details really neccesay?) I deduced some new leads and finally found the song: Coulter's Candy.  Apparently an old irish folk song.  The lyrics aren't quite what I remember, I can tell there are places where she must have changed the words.  
It's weird to think how distant the past is.  Or maybe it's just me.  Maybe I push the past away too much, focus so much on living now that I forget how I lived then.  It's like other people can go at length about their favorite Christmas, family gatherings, their first kiss, or other classic memorabe events, and I can bearly recally what I did last year.  Would this help explain my feeling of lack of self, that feeling like there are no unique charachters that define me as an individual?  Am I reading too much into this?  Will I get another comment about this being too sad?
ah well.
Poor wee soul, you're lookin' very thin
A puckle of bones covered over with skin
Now you're gettin' a wee double chin
From eatin' Coulter's candy

so Melissa suggested I started a live journal, and since all my creative efforts of current are going towards writing bad poetry, I figure why not?
I went to a poetry reading last night at Kiva Han.  It was pretty clicky in that "were all english majors and we rule" sort of way.  They called Dave "neuroscience boy".  They ignored me, as I pretty much did the same to them.  They had some pretty good stuff, much better than I expected.  Part of me wanted to go home and fill a blank book, but the majority of me realized that wouldn't be worth it.  Dave was certianly inspired, which is good since he was bitching a few days ago about not being able to write.
I tried to write some poems about my outlook on live, but they were all pretty grim.  I don't know what's wrong with me lately, i've felt okay, but I keep haveing really sad thought.  I think it's just me returning to a normative state of slightly higher depression than optimism.  You know, normal.
Damn, I should go write in my real journal.  Or at least leave work.  Do homework.  Have some candy.  All that good stuff.
